predictions: Zully Broussard donated a kidney to a stranger, triggering a chain reaction that resulted in six patients receiving transplants. A computer program, MatchGrid, matched donor-recipient pairs, making the process faster and more efficient. Broussard's generosity opened up 140 options for matching donors and recipients.

The MLS has made significant progress since its first match in 1996, with increased attendance, teams, and a new $700 million TV deal. Despite challenges, the league is growing, with world-class players like David Villa and Kaka joining, and a potential shift towards signing younger players.

French striker Bafetimbi Gomis collapsed during Swansea's match against Tottenham, but is "feeling well" after treatment. Gomis has a history of fainting due to low blood pressure. He spent the night in hospital as a precaution and thanked fans for their support and get well messages.

Rory McIlroy, the world's No. 1 golfer, threw his 3-iron into a lake after hitting a poor shot at the WGC Cadillac Championship. He composed himself to finish with a 70, but remains frustrated with his game, eight shots behind leader JB Holmes.

A Pennsylvania community is searching for 13-year-old Cayman Naib, who went missing on Wednesday. Hundreds of volunteers are helping with the search, which includes online efforts and foot searches. Cayman's parents believe he left impulsively after receiving an email from school about overdue homework.

Former MLB pitcher Curt Schilling defended his 17-year-old daughter Gabby on Twitter after she received vulgar and threatening comments from strangers. Schilling tracked down the offenders, resulting in two people losing their jobs, and is considering taking legal action to promote online accountability.

Two American women, aged 21 and 25, were arrested for carving their initials into a wall at Rome's Colosseum. They may face a fine for "aggravated damage" on a historical site, similar to a Russian tourist who was fined 20,000 euros for a similar offense last year.

Prince and 3rdEyeGirl are bringing their Hit & Run Tour to the U.S. for the first time, with the first show scheduled in Louisville, Kentucky on March 14. Tickets go on sale March 9, with a portion of sales donated to local charities. The venue has not been announced.

A shooting at a bar in Bamako, Mali, killed five people, including French and Belgian citizens, and wounded eight. Authorities called it a "criminal and terrorist act." Al-Murabitun, a North African jihadist group, claimed responsibility, citing retaliation for a leader's killing.

Manchester United's Jonny Evans and Newcastle United's Papiss Cisse have been charged by the Football Association for allegedly spitting at each other during a Premier League game. Both players deny intentionally spitting, and could face six-game bans if found guilty.

This article is about a CNN Student News program from March 10, 2015. The show covers international topics, including a solar-powered plane, mysterious craters in Asia, and a unique view of Mount Everest. It also invites schools to participate in the "Roll Call" segment.

ISIS-affiliated militants attacked Libya's Al-Ghani oil field, kidnapping 9 foreign workers, including 4 Filipinos, an Austrian, a Czech, a Ghanaian, and a Bangladeshi. The attack comes amid Libya's deteriorating security situation, with Islamic militias thriving and targeting oil fields.

Wichita North High School Principal Sherman Padgett was asked by a student to hold a bucket in the hallway. Students then filled it with notes of praise and thanks, sharing how he positively impacted their lives. The heartfelt gesture left Padgett emotional and grateful.

Comic book artist Norman Lee, 47, went missing while snorkeling in the Cayman Islands. The search is now a recovery mission due to strong currents. Tributes flooded social media from friends, fans, and colleagues, remembering him as a wonderful man and talented artist.

This article announces the topics to be covered on CNN Student News for March 9, 2015, including historic events like the Selma civil rights march and International Women's Day, as well as the U.S. unemployment report. It also invites schools to participate in the Roll Call segment.

Jessie Usher, star of Starz's "Survivor's Remorse," has been cast in Fox's "Independence Day 2" alongside Liam Hemsworth and Jeff Goldblum. Usher will play the son of Will Smith's character from the original film, set for release on June 24, 2016, nearly 20 years after the first film.

Former US Vice President Walter Mondale, 87, was released from the Mayo Clinic after being treated for influenza. Mondale, who served under President Jimmy Carter, was admitted after a routine checkup due to a fever. He is recovering and doing well, according to hospital officials and Carter.

Kyle Waring, a Massachusetts entrepreneur, is selling 6 pounds of Boston-area snow online for $89. He's filled over 133 orders, mostly from warm-weather states, with some companies buying it as a gag. Waring plans to expand his business to seasonal items like fall foliage.

In Jordan, thousands of refugee women, including Syrians, Iraqis, and Sudanese, are rebuilding their lives despite challenges. Organizations like the Near East Foundation provide vocational skills, financial literacy, and social support, empowering them to become earners and challenge cultural norms, but they still face abuse and violence.

Real Madrid lost 1-0 to Athletic Bilbao, potentially handing La Liga's top spot to Barcelona. Aritz Aduriz scored the winning goal. Real's coach Carlo Ancelotti expressed concern over his team's lack of attacking efficiency, having scored only one goal in two games.

A 40-year-old man in Japan's Sumoto city has been arrested for fatally stabbing five neighbors, including two couples and an 84-year-old woman. The victims lived near the suspect's home and shared the same surname, but their relation is unclear. The suspect admitted to the crime but refused further comment.

A car bomb exploded near a police vehicle in Lashkar Gah, Helmand province, Afghanistan, killing 7 people and injuring 23, including several children. The attack occurred at 6 p.m. in the Bolan area. The attacker's identity and motive are unknown. Most casualties were civilians.

Pakistan's highest court ordered the release of Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi, the alleged mastermind behind the 2008 Mumbai attacks that killed over 160 people. India strongly criticized the decision, summoning Pakistan's high commissioner to express their disappointment. Lakhvi, a Lashkar-e-Taiba leader, was granted bail last year.

A white police officer in DeKalb County, Georgia, shot and killed an unarmed, naked African-American man who charged at him. The officer was responding to a 911 call about a suspicious person. The case was immediately turned over to the Georgia Bureau of Investigations for an independent probe.

A viral photo shows a weasel riding on the back of a flying woodpecker near London. The image, taken by Martin Le-May, has been retweeted over 7,000 times. Experts say the weasel likely targeted the bird for food, but ultimately lost its grip and the bird flew away.

Kanye West fans are selling "bags of air" allegedly captured at his concerts on eBay, with prices reaching $60,000. The gag has inspired similar items, including "air-infused bay leaves" and "flatulence." Meanwhile, his Yeezy 750 Boost sneakers are being resold for up to $5,000.

A Delta Air Lines plane skidded into a fence at LaGuardia Airport due to brake issues during landing. The crew reported no deceleration despite auto brakes set to "max." 23 passengers received minor injuries. The NTSB is investigating, including examining weather conditions, to determine the cause of the accident.

In Pakistan, 107 schools in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa have been renamed to honor students killed in the 2014 Taliban siege at the Army Public School in Peshawar. The attack resulted in 145 deaths, mostly children, and was a tragic event that shocked the nation.

The Salvation Army in South Africa used the viral "#thedress" debate to raise awareness about domestic violence. An ad features a model in a white and gold dress with bruises, highlighting the illusion of choice in abuse. The ad received a mostly positive response.

NASCAR lifted its suspension of driver Kurt Busch, allowing him to return to racing under indefinite probation. The decision came after Delaware declined to file charges against him for alleged domestic violence. Busch must undergo additional behavioral steps and comply with judicial requirements to avoid further penalties.

A year after MH370's disappearance, an interim report reveals confusion and delays in the initial response. Air traffic controllers took 5 hours and 13 minutes to issue a distress signal, and search flights didn't take off for another 5 hours, potentially losing valuable time in the search effort.

A ferry capsized in Myanmar, killing 21 people and leaving 21 missing. The incident occurred near Sittwe, Rakhine state, due to bad weather. Authorities rescued 167 people. This is the latest in a series of fatal ferry disasters in the region, including a recent incident in Bangladesh.

Myanmar warplanes dropped a bomb in a Chinese sugarcane field, killing four civilians and wounding nine. China responded by sending fighter jets to patrol the border and summoned Myanmar's ambassador, demanding an investigation and justice for those responsible. Myanmar has not yet reacted to the incident.

The article discusses the risks of self-diagnosing online, citing 5 common mistakes: searching blindly, relying on untrustworthy forums, getting emotional, not sharing findings with doctors, and putting off medical appointments. Experts advise using reputable sources, being cautious, and consulting doctors for accurate diagnoses.

A 19-year-old man, Erich Nowsch Jr., has been indicted for murder, attempted murder, and firing a gun from a car in the fatal shooting of his 44-year-old neighbor, Tammy Meyers. Nowsch's attorney claims self-defense, while police say Meyers was shot in front of her home after a confrontation.

The article discusses strained US race relations, particularly between police and minority communities. It suggests community policing, foot patrols, and community events to build trust and foster mutual respect. Authorities' measured responses to recent incidents are seen as a step towards healing and positive change.

A North Korean diplomat was caught carrying 27kg of undeclared gold worth $1 million into Bangladesh's main airport. The diplomat initially refused a search, claiming the bag contained confidential items. The North Korean ambassador later apologized, and the diplomat has since left the country.

A 25-year-old mother, Lynn Jennifer Groesbeck, died in a car crash into a Utah river, but her 14-month-old daughter, Lily, survived 14 hours upside down in the car. Rescuers found Lily after a fisherman spotted the car. Her father says she's recovering well and singing nursery rhymes.

A medical helicopter carrying three employees from EagleMed LLC crashed in Eufaula, Oklahoma, while flying from Tulsa to McAlester. FAA investigators are on the scene. This incident comes after an Army Black Hawk helicopter crashed off the Florida Panhandle, resulting in the presumed deaths of 11 service members.

Monohm, a startup, is developing Runcible, a circular, palm-sized device that challenges the rectangular status quo of smartphones. Dubbed the "anti-smartphone," it aims to provide a more streamlined and less distracting digital experience, encouraging users to think differently about space and interaction.

The Star Wars universe is introducing its first gay character, Moff Mors, a lesbian Imperial official, in the upcoming novel "Lords of the Sith." This marks the first LGBTQ+ representation in the official Star Wars universe, as confirmed by Del Rey Books editor Shelly Shapiro.

In Lahore, Pakistan, two suicide bombers attacked a Christian community, killing 14 and wounding 78. The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility, warning of more attacks until Sharia law is implemented. The attack highlights the ongoing threat to Pakistan's Christian minority and other religious groups.

A massive IRS impersonation scam has swindled over $15 million from 3,000+ victims since 2013. Scammers, believed to be operating from India, use stolen identities and phishing technology to convince victims they owe money, threatening arrest or deportation. Authorities advise hanging up if you receive such a call.

The article discusses how the GOP's attempts to undermine President Obama's Iranian policy are not unique. It cites examples of past politicians, including Sen. Edward Kennedy and Richard Nixon, who have also interfered with foreign policy for partisan gain, highlighting the long history of partisanship in US foreign policy.

Pope Francis, 78, told a Mexican TV network he expects his papacy to be brief, lasting 2-5 years. He praised Pope Benedict XVI for reopening the door to popes emeritus and said he might follow suit. Francis also announced a "Jubilee of Mercy" starting in December.

Ashton Kutcher, a new father, posted on Facebook about the lack of diaper changing tables in public men's rooms. The post sparked a discussion with over 230,000 comments, with many praising him for raising the issue and advocating for more family-friendly facilities and gender equality.

Spain's Caminito del Rey, known as the "world's most dangerous path," reopens on March 26 after a decade-long closure. A 5.5 million euro reconstruction project restored the 7.7 km trail, featuring a 100m-high cliff face boardwalk. Entry is free for the first six months.

Isaac Herzog's Zionist Union party is leading in polls before Israel's election. Herzog, an underdog, promises social reform, working with the US on Iran, and restarting Palestinian peace talks. He comes from a prominent Israeli family and believes it's his destiny to be the next prime minister.

Hundreds of thousands of protesters in Brazil are calling for President Dilma Rousseff's impeachment due to economic woes and a massive scandal involving the national oil company, Petrobras. Rousseff, though not accused, faces pressure as protesters demand accountability for corruption during her time as Petrobras' board chairwoman.

Turkish officials detained 16 Indonesian citizens, including children, who confessed to planning to cross into Syria. The group was stopped in Gaziantep. Indonesia is sending a security team to investigate and cooperate with Turkish officials. This incident is separate from another group of 16 Indonesians who went missing in Turkey.

A Tamil news station in India was attacked with crude bombs after hardline Hindu groups took offense to a show about a traditional necklace. The incident highlights growing intolerance and censorship in India, where freedom of expression is guaranteed but often restricted by laws and violent protests.

Serena Williams returns to Indian Wells after a 14-year boycott, following a 2001 incident where she and her family faced racial abuse and accusations of match-fixing. Williams says she's "following her heart" in deciding to return, with her family's blessing, except for Venus and Richard Williams.

Kick It Out's mobile app has led to a 35% rise in reported racist incidents in football, with 184 incidents recorded in five months. The app allows fans to anonymously report incidents, triggering investigations by the English Football Association, and has been credited with helping to identify offenders.

Author Lisa Green advises parents of teens to have a criminal defense lawyer in mind due to the potential for severe, life-altering consequences from online or text actions. She suggests parents educate themselves on the law, know their child's rights, and be prepared for unexpected situations.

Spanish photographer Ignacio Evangelista's project "After Schengen" captures abandoned European border checkpoints 20 years after the Schengen agreement lifted frontier controls. His photos showcase the transformation of these once-bustling areas into ghostly, vacated spaces, reflecting Europe's evolving politics and allegiances.

Red Bull's Daniel Ricciardo reflects on the unpredictable nature of Formula One, citing his disqualification at the 2014 Australian Grand Prix due to a fuel flow rate issue. Despite past disappointments, he's eager to compete on his home turf and seek redemption in the upcoming season.

"Cinderella" debuted with $70.1 million, exceeding expectations. The live-action film, starring Lily James and Richard Madden, received strong reviews with an 83% Rotten Tomatoes rating. It topped the box office, followed by Liam Neeson's "Run All Night" in a distant second place.

Alabama officials investigated Harper Lee, 88, after an anonymous elder abuse complaint regarding her new book "Go Set a Watchman." Investigators found Lee understood the situation and wanted the book published. The investigation is closed, and the book remains scheduled for release.

A Navy veteran photographer posted a picture of a sailor holding a baby wrapped in the American flag, sparking debate. Some called it desecration, citing the U.S. Flag Code, while others saw it as a patriotic and beautiful representation of love for country and family.

Candida Moss, a professor of New Testament and Early Christianity, answers viewer questions about CNN's "Finding Jesus" series. Topics include the biblical significance of 40 days/nights, the relationship between Jesus and John the Baptist, DNA tests on relics, and extra-biblical sources on John the Baptist.

Apple's new smartwatch may have a "darker side." Research found that heavy users experience the "phantom device effect," compulsively checking their watch for information, even when not wearing it. This could lead to an unhealthy obsession with personal wellness and decreased attention to the world around them.

Police raided Robert Durst's Houston home after he was charged with first-degree murder in the 2000 death of his friend Susan Berman. Durst's attorney called the search "ridiculous" and claimed authorities were acting in response to the HBO documentary "The Jinx," which explored Durst's alleged connections to Berman's death.

The Southern Poverty Law Center reports a 17% decline in US hate groups from 2013 to 2014, with the Ku Klux Klan experiencing the largest decline. The decline may be due to a rebounding economy, law enforcement, and the high social cost of being associated with hate groups.

Rev. Fred Craddock, a renowned preacher, died at 86 in Blue Ridge, Georgia. He redefined preaching with his inductive, conversational style and was named one of the 12 most effective preachers in the English-speaking world. Craddock taught at Emory University's Candler School of Theology until his retirement.

The State Department only began automatically preserving high-level officials' emails last month, contradicting Hillary Clinton's claim that her emails to senior officials were always saved. This revelation may refuel controversy over Clinton's use of a private email server during her tenure as Secretary of State.

Two more American aid workers with high-risk Ebola exposure in Sierra Leone returned to the US for monitoring, bringing the total to 10. None are sick, but one worker in Nebraska was admitted to a biocontainment unit as a precaution after showing symptoms, which have since resolved.

Arsenal defeated Manchester United 2-1 in the FA Cup quarterfinals, with former United player Danny Welbeck scoring the winner. Nacho Monreal initially gave Arsenal the lead, but Wayne Rooney equalized before Welbeck capitalized on a mistake to secure the win, sending Arsenal to the semifinals.

The US Justice Department found a "pattern and practice" of racial discrimination in Ferguson, Missouri, where African-American residents were targeted for tickets and fines to generate revenue. A family's experience with the city's system, including a $1,200 fine for a "derelict vehicle," illustrates the issue.

Russian President Vladimir Putin appeared in photos meeting with the head of the Supreme Court after a week of canceled engagements sparked health speculation. Presidential spokesman Dmitry Peskov denied the rumors, joking they were due to "spring fever" and assuring Putin is "absolutely" healthy.

Paris Saint-Germain defeated Chelsea 2-2 (3-3 aggregate) in the Champions League, advancing on away goals. Thiago Silva scored the decisive goal after his earlier handball led to a Chelsea penalty. PSG played with 10 men for most of the game after Zlatan Ibrahimovic's red card.

The UK's Metropolitan Police has summoned five Chelsea football fans to court for alleged racism after a video showed them preventing a black man from boarding the Paris Metro and chanting racist slogans before a Champions League match. They face potential football banning orders and prison sentences.

Sotheby's is auctioning an untitled work by Italian sculptor Maurizio Cattelan, a black granite piece chronicling England's football defeats from 1874 to 1998. The piece, valued at $900,000, is a satirical work that pokes fun at England's football history, highlighting "pride, missed opportunities and death."

Tens of thousands gathered in Tel Aviv's Yitzhak Rabin Square, calling for a change in Israeli leadership. The rally, organized by One Million Hands, criticized Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's handling of a two-state solution and cost of living. Police estimated the crowd at 40,000 people.

The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame announced its 30th Annual Induction Ceremony lineup, featuring A-list presenters and performers. Paul McCartney, Patti Smith, Beck, and John Legend will participate, honoring inductees including Ringo Starr, Lou Reed, and Green Day. The ceremony airs on HBO May 30.

Tairod Nathan Webster Pugh, a 47-year-old US Air Force veteran, pleaded not guilty to terror-related charges for allegedly trying to join ISIS in Syria. He was turned back by Turkish authorities and arrested upon his return to the US, facing up to 35 years in prison if convicted.

Silicon Valley is erasing jobs, leaving millennials financially stranded. Despite low unemployment, 44% of young people are stuck in low-paying jobs, and only 36% of college grads have jobs paying at least $45,000. The digital economy is replacing good jobs with minimum wage and "sharing-economy" jobs.

The CSS Georgia, a Confederate ironclad ship, was recently excavated from the Savannah River, and many artifacts have been recovered. Among the artifacts are leg irons, cannons, and other items that provide insight into life on a Civil War ship.

In New Zealand, locals have taken to snatching car keys from foreign drivers due to concerns over tourist driving standards. Authorities condemn the vigilante actions, and the government is implementing measures to improve road safety and educate visiting drivers on local driving conditions.

Tropical Cyclone Pam brought "unbelievable destruction" to Vanuatu's capital, Port Vila, with winds of 155mph and 9 inches of rain. The storm, one of the strongest in the South Pacific, has left many homeless and in need of shelter, food, and water, with relief efforts underway.

In Esfahan, Iran, a thriving Jewish community openly practices their faith, with 13 synagogues and a Jewish representative in parliament. Despite Iran's hostility towards Israel, Iranian Jews feel at home and separate themselves from Israeli politics, seeking peace and unity with their Muslim neighbors.

Israel's upcoming election between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and opposition leader Isaac Herzog may not significantly change the country's policy, particularly regarding the Palestinian occupation. Both candidates lack a clear plan to end the occupation, with Herzog's approach being softer in tone but similar in substance.

A Turkish TV network released a video showing three British schoolgirls, believed to be Shamima Begum, Kadiza Sultana, and Amira Abase, preparing to cross the Turkish border into Syria to join ISIS. The footage, recorded on February 19, shows the girls with luggage and a man assisting them.

Kerry Washington will star as Anita Hill and executive produce HBO's TV movie "Confirmation," about the 1991 Clarence Thomas-Hill Supreme Court nomination hearings. Susannah Grant will write and executive produce, with Rick Famuyiwa in talks to direct. The project is in development from HBO Films.

47 Republican Senators sent a letter to Iran undermining President Obama's diplomatic efforts, sparking concerns of disrespect and potential Logan Act violations. This incident is part of a larger pattern of disrespect towards the President, with some attributing it to implicit racial bias and anti-Obama sentiment.

A CNN journalist interviewed Prince Charles at his Scottish home, Birkhall, discussing his 10-year marriage to Camilla and their upcoming US tour. Camilla declined an interview but allowed cameras to capture her public appearances, showcasing her charismatic personality. The couple appeared close and connected during the visit.

University of Virginia student leaders are hosting a campus forum with police to discuss allegations of brutality after the bloody arrest of 20-year-old Martese Johnson. The incident sparked protests and an independent investigation, amid a nationwide debate over police use of force, particularly against African-Americans.

Kelly Gissendaner, a death row inmate, underwent a transformation through a theology program and pastoral guidance. She found hope and redemption, becoming a source of inspiration to others. Her story has sparked a call for mercy and a reexamination of the Christian faith's teachings on forgiveness and redemption.

Boston police officers testified about the 2013 shootout with Boston Marathon bombing suspects Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. The officers described a chaotic scene with gunfire, bombs, and a stolen SUV. Tamerlan was killed, and Dzhokhar was later caught and is now on trial for the bombings.

An Army Black Hawk helicopter crashed in Florida waters, killing all 11 service members on board. The operation has transitioned from rescue to recovery, with the military focusing on retrieving the helicopter and bodies of the 7 Marines and 4 Louisiana Army National Guard members.

The bodies of four Italian tourists killed in the Tunis Bardo Museum terror attack arrived in Italy. Nineteen tourists from two cruise ships were among the 23 victims. Tunisian authorities identified two suspects and arrested nine people in connection with the attack, which ISIS claimed responsibility for.

Five residents in Ferguson, Missouri, have filed an affidavit to force a referendum on removing Mayor James Knowles, citing his failure to address police department issues following Michael Brown's death. Knowles has stated he won't step down, despite the city's police chief and manager resigning earlier.

Ozgecan Aslan, a 20-year-old Turkish university student, was murdered after fighting off a sexual assault on a bus. Her death sparked widespread protests, with hundreds of thousands demanding better protection for women in Turkey, where at least 281 women were killed in 2014.

Lindsey Vonn secured her 65th World Cup win in the super-G event at Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany, taking the lead in the speed discipline. She's now 35 points ahead of Anna Fenninger in downhill standings and aims for end-of-season glory at the finals in France.

Thousands of US children, with an average age of 13, are victims of sex trafficking. Two bills, the Justice for Victims of Trafficking Act and the Stop Exploitation Through Trafficking Act, aim to combat this issue by supporting victims and holding perpetrators accountable, and providing safe harbor provisions.

A social media campaign, "I will come to Tunisia," aims to support the country's tourism industry after a deadly attack at the Bardo Museum. Thousands have expressed solidarity with Tunisia, using hashtags like #JeSuisBardo and #PrayForTunisia, to show they will not be deterred by fear.

Former Wimbledon champion Marion Bartoli is considering a return to tennis after retiring in 2013 due to injuries. Eight-time grand slam champion Jimmy Connors advises her to only return if fully committed. Several female tennis stars, including Martina Hingis, have successfully come out of retirement in the past.

Actress Liza Minnelli, 68, has entered a rehab facility to treat her addictions to alcohol and painkillers. Her spokesman said she's making excellent progress. Minnelli has struggled with substance abuse in the past and has sought treatment when needed. She won an Oscar in 1973 for "Cabaret."

Zaur Dadayev, the primary suspect in Boris Nemtsov's murder, withdrew his confession, claiming he was tortured and coerced. Russian authorities accused human rights activists who visited him of "interfering" with the investigation, sparking Amnesty International's condemnation of the decision.

Ferguson, Missouri, is searching for a new police chief after Thomas Jackson's resignation. Experts say the ideal candidate should have empathy, confidence, and passion to bridge the community-police trust gap. They may look to Sanford, Florida, for guidance, where a new chief helped rebuild trust after the Trayvon Martin shooting.

March Madness, the NCAA Tournament, is a highly watched US sporting event where 68 college basketball teams compete. The tournament offers a stage for aspiring professionals to impress scouts, with top players potentially earning millions in the NBA. Smaller programs can produce successful NBA players.

Google CFO Patrick Pichette's resignation memo sparked debate on work-life balance. Critics argue that his decision to retire at 52 to travel with his wife is unattainable for most, highlighting the unrealistic expectations placed on working individuals, particularly women, to balance work and family responsibilities.

A.J. Pero, Twisted Sister's longtime drummer, died at 55 from a massive heart attack. Pero was on tour with Adrenaline Mob and was found unresponsive in his tour bus. Twisted Sister members, including Dee Snider, expressed their devastation and praised Pero's talent and dedication to the band.

Mexican wrestler Hijo del Perro Aguayo, 35, died after being kicked in the neck during a match. He collapsed and received delayed medical attention. An investigation into possible manslaughter has been opened, and the wrestling community is mourning the loss of the three-time Mexican National Tag Team champion.

New Zealand police are investigating a threat to contaminate infant formula with 1080 poison, a pest control measure, unless the government stops using it by March. Authorities say the threat is low, but have increased security and testing measures. A public appeal has been made to find the blackmailer.

Sigma Alpha Epsilon (SAE) is under fire after a video showed fraternity members singing a racist chant. The University of Oklahoma severed ties with SAE, citing a history of controversy, including hazing incidents, member deaths, and other safety concerns that have led to numerous chapter suspensions and closures.

Three iconic comic book characters unveiled new looks: Superman in a casual t-shirt and jeans, Wonder Woman in pants and body armor, and Archie Andrews with a modern makeover. These changes mark a significant shift in their classic styles, leaving fans to adjust to the new appearances.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu made a surprising comeback in the election, winning by a larger margin than polls predicted. Pollsters attribute the discrepancy to flawed methodology, biased online panels, and Netanyahu's strategic shift to the right, which drew votes from other right-wing parties.

A new HBO documentary, "Montage of Heck," offers an intimate look at Kurt Cobain's life. The film features interviews with family, Courtney Love, and Krist Novoselic. A companion book and soundtrack, including a 12-minute unheard acoustic track, will accompany the documentary, premiering on HBO on May 4.

US Secretary of State John Kerry stated that gaps remain in nuclear talks with Iran, but all parties agree Iran must not develop nuclear arms. Kerry emphasized the need for the right deal, rather than rushing to meet the March 24 deadline, to ensure Iran's nuclear program is peaceful.

Eleven US service members died in an Army Black Hawk helicopter crash off the Florida Panhandle. The victims, from the Marines and Louisiana National Guard, were decorated veterans with multiple deployments, including to Iraq, Afghanistan, and Kosovo, and leave behind families, friends, and a legacy of service and sacrifice.

The White House is defining a potential nuclear deal with Iran as a "nonbinding agreement" rather than a treaty, which would not require Senate approval. Republicans argue it's a treaty and should be treated as such, sparking a debate over executive authority and the limits of presidential power.

Jeremy Clarkson, Top Gear presenter, was suspended by the BBC after allegedly hitting a producer. Over 300,000 people signed a petition for his reinstatement, while others called for his sacking. The incident is the latest in a series of controversies surrounding Clarkson.

Dolce & Gabbana's Milan fashion show featured a collection dedicated to mothers. Models wore feminine dresses and skirts with lace, roses, and embroidered phrases like "I love you, mamma." The show included a tableau of moms and daughters, and some models carried their own children down the runway.

ISIS released a video showing a 19-year-old Israeli Arab, Mohamed Said Ismail Musallam, being shot by a child. Israel's Defense Minister denied ISIS' claim that Musallam was an Israeli spy, with Musallam's family stating he was recruited by ISIS and coerced into making false confessions.

Ferguson, Missouri, is a prime example of the US's broader policing problem, with racial bias and militarization exacerbating tensions. A complete overhaul of policing practices is needed, including diversifying police departments, rethinking military equipment use, and implementing community policing models to stem growing frustration and anger.

Two Chinese men, Han and Zhang, were jailed for selling military intelligence to foreign spies. Han received an 8-year sentence for taking photos of a military project, while Zhang received 6 years for sending over 500 photos of China's Liaoning aircraft carrier to a foreign magazine.

Melissa Benoist stars as Supergirl in the new CBS series. The first-look photos show Benoist in the official costume, designed by Oscar-winner Colleen Atwood. The drama follows Kara Zor-El, Superman's cousin, as she navigates her powers and life on Earth. Production has begun in Los Angeles.

The article discusses how recent actions by Republican senators and Hillary Clinton have deepened polarization in US politics. The senators' letter to Iran and Clinton's handling of her emails have created divisive issues that will likely persist through the 2016 presidential campaign and beyond.

A 12-year-old boy, Wyatt, born with a limb difference, is receiving a free electronic robotic arm from University of Central Florida students. The arm, made using a 3D printer, allows him to open and close his hand by flexing his bicep, giving him new possibilities and independence.

The author reflects on traditional household gender roles, comparing their childhood to the TV show "Leave It to Beaver." They argue that even with progress, women still bear a disproportionate burden of household labor, and men must take responsibility to create more equitable relationships and value household work.

Larry David's Broadway play "Fish in the Dark" has sparked controversy over its depiction of a Puerto Rican maid, while the National Asian Artists Project canceled its all-Asian adaptation of "Show Boat" due to concerns about cultural insensitivity and appropriation.

Ben Stiller and Owen Wilson reprised their "Zoolander" roles at Paris Fashion Week's Valentino show. They walked the runway, with Stiller as Derek Zoolander and Wilson as Hansel McDonald, promoting the upcoming "Zoolander 2" film, set for release in February 2016.

The University of Oklahoma is hiring a vice president to oversee diversity programs after a racist video surfaced of the now-disbanded Sigma Alpha Epsilon fraternity. Two students were expelled, and the university cut ties with the fraternity. The national fraternity is investigating other incidents.

Jeremy Clarkson's popularity endures despite controversies, including alleged staff abuse and racist remarks. His calculated indiscretions boost his profile, and his fans defend him. The BBC is deliberating his future, but his "charmed life" may continue, with his stock growing with every controversy.

University of Oklahoma President David Boren swiftly condemned a racist video by fraternity members, severing ties with the fraternity and expelling two students. His decisive action has resonated nationwide, shifting social norms and sparking a call for a broader reckoning with racism and institutional bias.

A Palestinian man in his 20s rammed into a cyclist and four Israeli border police in Jerusalem, injuring them lightly to moderately. He was shot and severely wounded by a security guard while trying to escape. Authorities are treating the incident as a terror attack, with Hamas applauding the act.

The National Gallery in London has banned selfie sticks, joining institutions like the Smithsonian and New York's Museum of Modern Art. The ban aims to prevent invasion of personal space and potential damage to art. Selfie sticks are still allowed outside the museum for other attractions.

The article criticizes the Republican Congress for manufacturing a crisis by threatening to shut down the Department of Homeland Security over immigration disputes. This move puts national security at risk and prioritizes scoring "cheap political points" over serving the middle class, marking a pattern of dysfunctional governance.

Cody Simpson is promoting the U.N.'s International Day of Happiness with the #HappySoundsLike playlist. He'll perform at SXSW and selected Bob Marley's "Three Little Birds" for the playlist. Other celebs, including Britney Spears and Pharrell, also contributed to the playlist to spread happiness through music.

At the Gridiron Club dinner, President Obama joked about marijuana legalization in D.C. and Hillary Clinton's email controversy. Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker also attended, addressing Rudy Giuliani's comments about Obama's love for America. The event is known for allowing politicians to poke fun at themselves and others.

A 1,000-year-old mummified monk was stolen from a Chinese temple in 1995 and resurfaced in the Netherlands. Chinese relic experts claim ownership and are seeking repatriation. The mummy, found inside a Buddha statue, is believed to be a self-mummified Buddhist monk named Liuquan.

Penn State University's Kappa Delta Rho fraternity was suspended after posting compromising photos of women, including some asleep or passed out, on a private Facebook page. The university is investigating and considering re-evaluating the fraternity system, citing concerns about the handling of sex crime reports.

On March 25, 2015, CNN Student News covered major stories, including the US maintaining troop levels in Afghanistan, Israel denying spying on US-Iran negotiations, and a plane crash in the French Alps. The show also featured a CNN Hero helping young people with eye and ear health.

Parisa Tabriz, Google's 31-year-old "Security Princess," hacks into Chrome to find flaws before "black hat" hackers do. With over 500 security engineers, she combats cybercrime, including government surveillance and bug exploitation. Tabriz also promotes diversity in tech and challenges stereotypes in her field.

A previously unknown group, the Islamic State Hacking Division, posted online the names, photos, and addresses of about 100 U.S. troops, calling for attacks. Authorities are investigating the claim, but the information appears to be publicly available through social media and online directories.

Serena Williams returned to Indian Wells after a 14-year boycott, following a 2001 incident where she and her family faced racial abuse. She received a standing ovation and won her match, calling it one of her "proudest moments" and a "huge win" for herself and others.

Chuck Norris is celebrating his 75th birthday, born on March 10, 1940. However, according to his humorous reputation, the calendar is only allowed to turn 39, implying he can defy time. The article pokes fun at his tough-guy image with various jokes and one-liners.

Serena Williams is ending her 13-year boycott of the Indian Wells tennis tournament, where she was booed and faced racist remarks in 2001. She sought her parents' approval, who encouraged her to return, and is now competing in the spirit of forgiveness and to show her strength.

Pi Day, celebrated on March 14, is extra special in 2015 as the date aligns with 3.1415. The Exploratorium in San Francisco started the tradition 27 years ago. This year's events include a Pi Procession, pie-eating, and an Einstein lookalike contest, as it's also Albert Einstein's birthday.

The remains of Richard III, discovered in 2012, are to be reburied after years of research. Analysis revealed he likely had blue eyes and blond hair, not the dark-haired, hunchbacked figure of Shakespeare's portrayal. His diet was rich, and he suffered from a roundworm infection when he died.

Tom Hanks stars in Carly Rae Jepsen's "I Really Like You" music video, lip-syncing to her song. He's friends with Jepsen's manager, Scooter Braun, and suggested himself for the role. The result is a magical and entertaining video featuring Hanks and a flash mob.

A federal judge ordered the Defense Department to release photos of detainee abuse in Iraq and Afghanistan during the Bush administration. The government has 60 days to appeal. The ACLU sued for the photos' release, arguing they're essential to understanding the implications of the administration's policies.

Singer-songwriter David Crosby accidentally hit a jogger with his car in Santa Ynez, California. The jogger suffered multiple fractures but non-life-threatening injuries. Crosby was cooperative and not impaired; he didn't see the jogger due to the sun. He expressed relief and wished the jogger a speedy recovery.

Coalition airstrikes began in Tikrit, Iraq, targeting ISIS strongholds. The strikes, requested by Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi, aim to support Iraqi forces in retaking the city. Success in Tikrit could pave the way for recapturing Mosul, a larger city held by ISIS since 2014.

Denise Huskins, 29, was found safe in Huntington Beach, California, 400 miles from her reported kidnapping in Vallejo. She was dropped off at her father's apartment complex with no apparent injuries. The case is being treated as a kidnap for ransom, with the FBI involved.

Retired NFL star Darren Sharper pleaded guilty to one count of sexual assault and one count of attempted sexual assault in Arizona. He was sentenced to 9 years in prison with no early release eligibility and lifetime probation. Sharper will receive 300 days credit for time served in California.

Germanwings Flight 4U 9525 crashed with 150 on board. Initial clues include a recovered "black box," a rapid descent, and no distress call. Experts say the pilot was controlling the plane to some extent, but the cause of the crash remains unknown and will take months to determine.

The National Institutes of Health will admit an American healthcare worker with Ebola to its Maryland hospital. The patient, who contracted the disease in Sierra Leone, will be flown to the US on a chartered aircraft. This is the second Ebola patient to be treated at the NIH hospital.

The VA is undermining the Veterans Access, Choice and Accountability Act by limiting veterans' access to local healthcare. The VA's narrow interpretation of the 40-mile rule denies care to those living near VA facilities that don't offer needed services, prompting new legislation to fix the issue.

Angelina Jolie underwent surgery to remove her ovaries and fallopian tubes due to a BRCA1 gene mutation, which increases her cancer risk. She had previously had a double mastectomy. Jolie urges women with the mutation to explore their options and take control of their health.

BBC suspends "Top Gear" host Jeremy Clarkson following a physical altercation with a producer. Over 147,000 people signed a petition for his reinstatement. Clarkson has a history of controversy, including using a racist term and sparking outrage in Argentina with a Falklands War reference.

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints claims to have strong measures in place to prevent child abuse in its Boy Scout troops. However, a CNN investigation found allegations of abuse, including a case where a scoutmaster was allowed to rejoin scouting despite being previously removed.

J.K. Rowling responded to a fan questioning Dumbledore's gay identity, saying "Maybe because gay people just look like... people?" The fan couldn't envision Dumbledore as gay, prompting Rowling's concise and impactful reply, which was well-received by her fans.

A reported kidnapping in Vallejo, California, turned out to be a hoax. Denise Huskins, 29, was found safe in Huntington Beach after her boyfriend reported her kidnapping for ransom. Both Huskins and her boyfriend are no longer cooperating with police, and charges are possible.

Rohana Rozhan, CEO of Astro Malaysia, a $4.6 billion media company, was nicknamed "Rohana the Piranha" as a child. She's fiercely independent and leads a company producing 9,000 hours of original content yearly, with 52% female employees, emphasizing hard work and respect.

Jon Hamm, the actor who plays Don Draper on "Mad Men," completed a 30-day rehab stint for alcohol abuse at Silver Hill Hospital in Connecticut. His representatives confirmed the news, asking for privacy. Filming for the show's final episodes was completed months prior to his rehab stay.

Creflo Dollar, a prosperity preacher, is seeking $60 million in donations to buy a $65 million Gulfstream G650 jet. He claims the luxury jet is needed to transport him and his team globally to spread the gospel, citing safety concerns with his current 30-year-old jet.

A new study suggests Neanderthals were more cognitively advanced than previously thought. Researchers found 130,000-year-old eagle talons in Croatia with cut marks and notches, indicating they were modified into jewelry. This discovery shows Neanderthals had sophisticated skills and possibly advanced planning abilities, challenging their caveman-like stereotype.

Two University of Oklahoma students, Parker Rice and Levi Pettit, were expelled for their roles in a racist fraternity video. Both apologized, with Rice calling his actions "wrong and reckless" and Pettit's parents stating he made a "horrible mistake" and is not a racist.

A British mother defended her 11-year-old son's "Fifty Shades of Grey" costume for World Book Day, despite the school deeming it inappropriate. The mother argued that a teacher's "Dexter" costume was more violent, and the school's reaction was an overreaction to a lighthearted joke.

A Washington state driver used a cardboard cutout of "The Most Interesting Man in the World" to try to use the HOV lane. A trooper caught him and issued a $124 ticket, praising the driver's creativity but noting a less recognizable face might have worked better.

A storm system in Oklahoma killed one person, injured about two dozen others, and caused significant damage. A reported tornado destroyed a mobile home park and a gymnastics studio. Gov. Mary Fallin declared a state of emergency for 25 counties, with severe weather reported across the Tulsa metro area.

The article argues that the US has been underfunding its military, despite growing threats from the Islamic State, Russia, and China. The authors propose increasing defense spending to the levels proposed by former Defense Secretary Robert Gates to address the funding gap and ensure military readiness.

A massive winter storm spans 2,000 miles from New Mexico to southern New England, affecting 94 million people. Over 1,100 flights were canceled at Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport, and the federal government is closed on Thursday due to the severe weather conditions.

Detroit police discovered the bodies of a 14-year-old girl and an 11-year-old boy inside a freezer during an eviction. The mother was arrested on child abuse charges. Two older children were placed in protective custody. Autopsies are pending, and the investigation is ongoing.

Russian President Vladimir Putin appeared in public after a 10-day absence, meeting with Kyrgyz President Almazbek Atambayev in St. Petersburg. His appearance, looking healthy and relaxed, aimed to quell rumors about his health and grip on power that had been circulating on social media.

Scientists suggest Jupiter's migration in the early solar system destroyed "super-Earths" and cleared the way for the formation of smaller planets like Earth, Mercury, Venus, and Mars. Jupiter's inward-outward journey bulldozed planetesimals, sending them into the sun and paving the way for the current inner solar system.

Two U.S. citizens, Army National Guard member Hasan Edmonds and his cousin Jonas Edmonds, were arrested for allegedly conspiring to support ISIS. Hasan planned to join ISIS in Egypt, while Jonas plotted to attack a U.S. military facility in Illinois, potentially killing 100-150 people.

Jeremy Clarkson and the Top Gear crew faced an angry mob in Argentina due to a car's registration plate referencing the 1982 Falklands War. Clarkson has a history of controversy, including racist comments and offending locals during shoots, leading to his suspension by the BBC.

A new book, "Becoming Steve Jobs," presents a kinder portrait of the Apple co-founder, contradicting Walter Isaacson's 2011 biography. Apple executives praise the new book, criticizing Isaacson's version as inaccurate. The book offers fresh insights into Jobs' life, including his final days and personal relationships.

Actress Taraji P. Henson apologized for claiming her son was racially profiled during a traffic stop in Glendale, California. Dash cam footage contradicted her son's claims, showing he was stopped for failing to yield and was found with marijuana and other substances.

Experts answered viewer questions about Germanwings Flight 9525. Topics included the slow descent rate, lack of crash prevention technology, live cameras, hacking possibilities, the absence of a fiery explosion, and the potential influence of medication or drugs on the co-pilot.

Gareth Bale scored twice as Wales beat Israel 3-0 in Euro 2016 qualification, taking them to the top of their group. This puts Wales on course for their first major finals since the 1958 World Cup. Bale dominated the game, also setting up Arsenal's Aaron Ramsay for the first goal.

Philip Kusseler's Wait A Little horse safaris offers a unique way to experience Africa's wildlife on horseback. Retired thoroughbreds are trained for the task, providing a thrilling and intimate encounter with nature's beasts, including the "Big Five" game, in South Africa's Karongwe and Greater Makalali Game Reserves.

Nigeria's military has retaken the northeastern town of Gwoza from Boko Haram, the militant group's declared "caliphate" headquarters. The victory comes on the eve of Nigeria's general elections, with President Goodluck Jonathan praising the military's efforts and warning against election violence.

Protests and violence erupted in Nigeria's Rivers state over alleged election rigging, threatening the country's peaceful election pledge. The opposition party claims voters were intimidated, while the ruling party says the election was credible. Fears of post-election violence have led both candidates to call for calm on social media.

Italy's high court has overturned the guilty verdicts for Amanda Knox and Raffaele Sollecito in the 2007 murder of Meredith Kercher. The decision is final, and they are now cleared of all charges. The Kercher family is disappointed and may appeal to the European Court of Human Rights.

Tropical Cyclone Pam devastated Vanuatu, a Pacific island nation, with 155mph winds, killing 11 and leaving thousands homeless. The storm destroyed 90% of houses in the capital, Port Vila, and aid groups warn of a humanitarian crisis, with 60,000 children in need of assistance.

A bipartisan summit on criminal justice reform is taking place, featuring heavyweights from both parties. The event aims to safely halve the US prison population within 10 years, with conservatives and liberals finding common ground on issues like liberty, justice, and fiscal responsibility.

Zayn Malik, 22, has left One Direction after five years. The remaining members will continue as a four-piece, with a world tour and fifth album planned. Fans reacted with sadness on social media, causing a 330% spike in global streams of One Direction songs on Spotify.

Zayn Malik, former One Direction member, apologized for the pain caused by his departure. He stated he couldn't continue as it wasn't the "real me." Malik is working on a solo project and remains on good terms with the other band members, who will continue as a foursome.

The first trailer for James Bond's 24th film, "SPECTRE," has been released. Daniel Craig reprises his role as Bond, who must infiltrate a global terrorist organization after a cryptic message from his past. The trailer offers clues to the plot, picking up where "Skyfall" left off.

Russian President Vladimir Putin's sudden disappearance sparked speculation about his health and whereabouts, with social media users questioning the authenticity of released photos. The incident highlights the country's lack of transparency and raises concerns about a potential power vacuum if Putin were to leave office.

Charlottesville Police found no evidence to support a University of Virginia student's claim of being raped at a fraternity house, as reported by Rolling Stone. The magazine apologized for discrepancies and is conducting an independent review, expected to be published in early April.

Kylie Minogue will perform a 90-minute show at the 20th Dubai World Cup, a $30 million horse racing event. The pop star expressed excitement, citing her Australian upbringing where horse racing is a major event. Luxury brands will sponsor races and offer prizes for best-dressed attendees.

Thousands of protesters marched in Tunisia's capital against terrorism, two weeks after a deadly museum attack. Tunisian President Beji Caid Essebsi and world leaders joined the rally, which included chants of "Tunisia is free, and out with terrorism." The alleged attack architect was killed in a raid earlier that day.

A coffin made by Michael Ibsen, a distant relative of Richard III, will be the final resting place of the English King. Ibsen's DNA helped identify Richard III's remains, found in a Leicester car park in 2012. The coffin will be part of a reburial ceremony next week.

Sen. Harry Reid's retirement announcement has sparked a potential leadership battle among Senate Democrats. Chuck Schumer is favored to succeed Reid, but left-leaning activists are pushing for Sen. Elizabeth Warren or other challengers, citing Schumer's ties to Wall Street.

Seven college-age people were wounded in a late-night shooting in Panama City Beach, Florida, during spring break. Authorities arrested 22-year-old David Jarmichael Daniels on seven counts of attempted murder. Three victims were in critical condition, and the city council considered measures to address the violence.

A Germanwings Airbus A320 crashed in the French Alps, killing all 150 on board. The cause is unknown, but one black box has been found. Relatives gathered at Barcelona airport, and a crisis center was set up. Recovery efforts are complicated by snow and remote location.

AMC's "The Walking Dead" companion series has been officially titled "Fear The Walking Dead." The prequel series, set in Los Angeles, follows new characters and storylines at the onset of the zombie outbreak. It will premiere in late summer, with a second season set for 2016.

Kentucky dominated West Virginia 78-39, advancing to the Elite Eight with a 37-0 record. Notre Dame and Wisconsin also advanced with wins over Wichita State and North Carolina. Arizona beat Xavier 68-60, setting up a rematch with Wisconsin in the Elite Eight.

Lewis Hamilton secured pole position for the Malaysian Grand Prix, beating Sebastian Vettel and Nico Rosberg in torrential conditions. Tensions between Hamilton and Rosberg were downplayed after an incident during qualifying. Max Verstappen impressed with a sixth-place start in his second Toro Rosso race.

Yemen's President Abdu Rabu Mansour Hadi joined allies in Egypt as Saudi-led airstrikes intensified against Houthi rebels in Sanaa. The Arab League is expected to bless the operation, potentially paving the way for a ground invasion. Dozens of civilians have been killed in the strikes.

A commuter train collided with a car near the University of Southern California campus in Los Angeles, injuring 21 people. 10 were hospitalized, with 2 in critical and grave condition. The derailment caused traffic concerns for a nearby soccer game, prompting Metro to request shuttle buses.

Germanwings Flight 9525 crashed into the Alps, killing 150 people. Co-pilot Andreas Lubitz, 28, deliberately crashed the plane by manipulating the flight monitoring system while the pilot was out. Lubitz's actions were revealed through a mangled cockpit voice recorder and investigation.

A supporter of suspended "Top Gear" host Jeremy Clarkson delivered a petition with nearly 1 million signatures to the BBC's London headquarters, calling for his reinstatement. Clarkson was suspended for allegedly hitting a producer, sparking outrage among fans and a global audience of 350 million viewers.

The community of Montoursville, Pennsylvania, offers condolences to Haltern am See, Germany, after the Germanwings Flight 9525 crash. They share their own experience of losing 16 students and 5 chaperones in the TWA Flight 800 crash 19 years ago, offering support and understanding in their grief.

The Germanwings crash highlights the incompatibility between the perceived professionalism of pilots and the reality that they are human, prone to flaws and unpredictable behavior. Pilots are not inherently more responsible or moral, but rather ordinary people in a highly controlled environment, making them capable of catastrophic acts.

On March 30, 2015, CNN Student News covered Nigerian elections, an astronaut's 340-day space mission, and a fire-extinguishing invention using low-frequency sound waves. The show transcript is available, and students can request to be on the Roll Call by commenting with their school information.

Manchester United defeated Tottenham 3-0, boosting their Champions League qualification chances. Goals from Marouane Fellaini, Michael Carrick, and Wayne Rooney secured the win, leaving United in fourth place and Tottenham seventh. Rooney's goal celebration mocked a recent "friendly" boxing match video.

Thousands of Singaporeans gathered in the rain to bid farewell to founding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, who died at 91. Foreign dignitaries attended the funeral, honoring his role in transforming Singapore into a wealthy financial center, despite criticism for curbing media freedoms and restricting civil rights.

Houthi rebels seized the international airport in Taiz, Yemen, amid a "rapid downward spiral" towards civil war. The UN envoy warned of escalating violence, with 1 civilian killed and 82 wounded. The US has pulled its remaining personnel due to the deteriorating security situation.

A video of Beauton Gilbow, the house mother of the University of Oklahoma's Sigma Alpha Epsilon chapter, surfaced, showing her singing a rap song with the n-word. Despite the controversy, two black alumni defended her, saying she's not racist and was "caught up in the moment."

A 475-pound leatherback sea turtle, named Yawkey, was rescued in South Carolina, marking the state's first and the US's fifth live rescue of this species. The juvenile turtle is being treated at the South Carolina Aquarium and is expected to be released back into the ocean within days.

ISIS claimed responsibility for the deadly terrorist attack at the Bardo Museum in Tunis, killing 23 people, including tourists and locals. The attack has shaken Tunisia, the birthplace of the Arab Spring, and raised concerns about the country's struggle with extremism and its impact on the economy.

Nuclear talks between world powers and Iran intensified in Lausanne, Switzerland, with key issues unresolved ahead of a Tuesday deadline. Disagreements remain on limits to Iranian research and development, and the pace of lifting UN sanctions, with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu warning the emerging deal is "worse than our deepest fears."

A California jury ruled that Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams' "Blurred Lines" infringed on Marvin Gaye's 1977 song "Got to Give It Up." Thicke and Williams were ordered to pay $4 million in damages and $3.4 million in profits, totaling $7.4 million.

Over 54% of the world's population lives in cities, with 66% predicted by 2050. Africa's cities are booming, with Cairo, Tunis, and Johannesburg ranking top in infrastructure and human capital. However, sub-Saharan cities like Dar es Salaam and Nairobi show strong growth trajectories for future investment.

Trevor Noah will replace Jon Stewart as host of "The Daily Show." Stewart, who hosted for 16 years, approves of the 31-year-old South African comedian. Noah has made three appearances on the show and will take over after Stewart's departure.

In Lagos, Nigeria, "free readers associations" gather around newspaper vendors to read and debate headlines. Vendors welcome the groups, seeing them as advertisements, and offer affordable reading options. The associations bring people together, fostering friendships and discussions, despite a decline in readers due to internet and economic challenges.

India's Supreme Court has struck down Section 66A of the 2008 Information Technology Act, deeming it "unconstitutional" for its vague wording that could curb freedom of expression. The law allowed for up to three years in jail for posting "grossly offensive" or "menacing" content online.

Three California educators were arrested for operating a "pay-to-stay" scheme, collecting $6 million in tuition from 1,500 foreign students who never attended classes. The students, mostly from South Korea and China, lived in other states on student visas, compromising national security and immigration laws.

The Duchess of Cambridge made her last official appearance before giving birth to her second child. She and Prince William visited the Stephen Lawrence Centre and a church in London, accompanied by Baroness Lawrence. The Duchess is expected to give birth in mid- to late April.

A psychologist reflects on the Germanwings Flight 9525 crash, attributing the tragedy to human error. He advocates for more rigorous psychological screening and regular testing for pilots, acknowledging that human unpredictability will always be a factor in aviation accidents, making prevention a complex challenge.

Sam Taylor-Johnson won't direct "Fifty Shades Darker," the sequel to "Fifty Shades of Grey." She cited an "intense and incredible journey" but wished success to the next director. Creative clashes and author E L James' control over the screenplay may have contributed to Taylor-Johnson's departure.

Golf legend Arnold Palmer, 85, vows to hit the ceremonial opening tee shot at the Masters despite a dislocated shoulder. Palmer, a four-time Masters champion, plans to join Jack Nicklaus and Gary Player on the course, even though doctors haven't cleared him to swing a golf club yet.

Iranian President Hassan Rouhani says a nuclear deal with international powers is within reach, citing new common ground. US Secretary of State John Kerry also reports "substantial progress" but notes gaps remain. Negotiations continue, with a March 31 deadline for a framework pact.

In China, 61 million "left-behind children" are raised by grandparents or relatives while their parents work in cities. This leads to struggles in school, mental health issues, and behavioral problems. The hukou system, which restricts access to social services, exacerbates the problem, affecting a generation's security and trust.

Afghan President Ashraf Ghani's visit to Washington may lead to direct peace talks with the Taliban. However, a successful agreement is unlikely due to challenges such as the Taliban's strong negotiating position, potential splinter groups, and the Afghan government's struggles to govern.

Iraqi forces, backed by Shia militias, have captured key areas in Tikrit, including the governorate and main hospital, after a slow advance due to over 300 IEDs. At least 26 militants were killed, and the gains follow a series of U.S.-led airstrikes targeting ISIS around the city.

Hillary Clinton is facing controversy over her private email account and server as Secretary of State. Despite Republican criticism, Clinton has a history of resilience in the face of scandal, using tactics such as attacking accusers, waiting out the news cycle, and rallying her party base.

Swedish prosecutors have asked Julian Assange to consent to an interview and DNA swab in London, a change in approach due to the statute of limitations expiring in August 2015. Assange's team views the request positively, but notes it may take time due to involvement of multiple countries.

New Zealand reached their first World Cup final after a thrilling semifinal win over South Africa. Grant Elliott hit a six off the penultimate ball to secure victory, chasing an adjusted target of 298 in 43 overs. They will face either Australia or India in the final.

In China, a growing number of young people are rediscovering Buddhism, seeking spiritual anchor in a competitive society. Many are drawn to Tibetan Buddhism, finding comfort in meditation and volunteering. However, combining Buddhist beliefs with modern life can be challenging, especially in a secular society.

A truck bomb exploded at an Egyptian security camp in Al-Arish, North Sinai, killing a civilian and the driver, and injuring 44 people, including 42 soldiers. No group has claimed responsibility. The attack is the latest in a series of militant attacks in the volatile Sinai Peninsula.

Al-Shabaab militants attacked government offices in Baidoa, Somalia, killing nine people, including four attackers. The attack began with a car bomb and heavy gunfire. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility, and the African Union condemned the attack as a desperate attempt to seek relevance after suffering defeats from Somali and AU troops.

Eugenie Bouchard and Justin Bieber teamed up for a doubles tennis match at the Desert Smash charity event in California. Bouchard praised Bieber's "nice serve" on Twitter, but he hasn't responded. The event supported Cancer for College, a charity providing scholarships for students who've battled cancer.

Iran nuclear negotiations have made progress, but Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has expressed concerns. If a deal is reached, Israel's options are limited. A military strike could have severe consequences, including damaging relations with the P5+1, sparking Iranian retaliation, and collapsing international sanctions.

Kenya is the world's third-largest exporter of cut flowers, accounting for 35% of EU sales. The country's sunny climate and excellent transport links make it an ideal location for growing high-quality flowers. The industry supports over 500,000 people and generates around $600m annually.

Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson hosted "Saturday Night Live" and appeared in memorable sketches, including a live-action "Bambi" remake and a promo spoofing the WWE. He also made a surprise appearance at WrestleMania 31, teaming up with Ronda Rousey to take on WWE executives.

Approximately 150 homeless people visited the Vatican, touring the Vatican Museums, Sistine Chapel, and other areas. The Office of Papal Charities arranged the visit, led by Archbishop Konrad Krajewski, to give the poor a chance to experience the Vatican's artistic heritage, usually reserved for paying visitors.

The UK Supreme Court ruled that previously secret correspondence between Prince Charles and government officials must be made public. The Guardian newspaper had been fighting for the release since 2005, citing concerns that Charles may be a "meddling king" who could influence politicians as monarch.

The article discusses the decline of tigers in India due to human-tiger conflict, rather than poaching. Conservation efforts, including tiger conflict mediation, have led to a 30% increase in India's tiger population. However, the growing human population poses a significant challenge to maintaining a healthy tiger population.

Indiana's Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) sparked controversy over potential anti-LGBT discrimination. Gov. Pence initially defended the law, but later called for a "fix." Two possible solutions exist: adopting statewide nondiscrimination laws or amending the RFRA to exempt local nondiscrimination ordinances, but both face opposition.

Jordan Spieth won the Valspar Championship in a three-way playoff, becoming the fourth player since 1940 to win twice on the PGA Tour before turning 22. He now sets his sights on Rory McIlroy and the world No.1 spot, gaining confidence ahead of the four majors.

This article is about the April 1, 2015, episode of CNN Student News. The episode covers global events, U.S. wages, and the potential use of cyborg cockroaches as rescuers. It also invites students to participate in the Roll Call by commenting with their school information.

Lewis Hamilton won the Australian Grand Prix, leading a Mercedes one-two with teammate Nico Rosberg. Sebastian Vettel took third for Ferrari. Hamilton's 34th career victory underlined Mercedes' dominance, with only 11 cars finishing the 58-lap race.

Michael Douglas wrote about his 14-year-old son Dylan's encounter with anti-Semitism in southern Europe. Dylan was wearing a Star of David when a man hurled insults at him. Douglas calls for collective action to combat anti-Semitism, using his platform to denounce it and promote reconciliation.

Researchers recreated a 1,000-year-old Anglo-Saxon "eyesalve" remedy from Bald's Leechbook, using garlic, onion, wine, and oxgall. The potion showed remarkable effectiveness against MRSA, killing up to 90% of bacteria in lab tests and mouse wound biopsies, offering potential as a new antibiotic treatment.

Benjamin Netanyahu backtracked on his pre-election statement that there would be no Palestinian state if he were Prime Minister. The US and Palestinians remain skeptical, with the Palestinians considering another UN bid for recognition and the US reassessing its relationship with Israel.

Indiana's new "religious freedom" law allows businesses to turn away gay and lesbian customers if serving them would contravene the business owner's religious beliefs. The law has sparked a heated debate on social media, with some calling for a boycott.

London's Fourth Plinth unveiled "Gift Horse," a 13-foot bronze skeleton of a horse with a live stock ticker, created by Hans Haacke. The sculpture explores the link between power, money, and history, and is the 10th artwork to sit on the plinth in Trafalgar Square.

Adam West and Burt Ward announced at the Mad Monster Party they will reprise their roles as Batman and Robin in an upcoming 90-minute animated feature, possibly one of two projects, to coincide with the 50th anniversary of the 1960s Batman TV series in 2016.

Talks on Iran's nuclear program in Lausanne, Switzerland, have been extended an extra day. Diplomats are working to reach a framework agreement, with progress made but gaps remaining. Key issues include sanctions relief, nuclear technology advancement, and sanctions snapback. A final deal deadline is June 30.

BBC Director-General Tony Hall received death threats via email from outside the UK after deciding not to renew Jeremy Clarkson's "Top Gear" contract. The decision followed an altercation between Clarkson and a producer. Police are investigating the threats, which came after over 1 million fans signed a petition to reinstate Clarkson.

Maria Shriver on the Oscar win for "Still Alice": The film shines a light on Alzheimer's, a disease affecting 5 million Americans, with women disproportionately impacted. The Wipe Out Alzheimer's Challenge aims to educate, engage, and empower women to drive change and fund research into the disease.

A Canadian tourist, Jennifer Karren, 35, was killed when a tour boat collided with a whale off Cabo San Lucas, Mexico. Two others were injured. The boat's captain tried to avoid the whale, and CPR was performed on Karren, but she was pronounced dead at the hospital.

Ivory Coast's former first lady Simone Gbagbo has been sentenced to 20 years in prison for her role in crimes against humanity following post-election violence in 2010 that left over 3,000 people dead.

Donald Trump retrieved Rory McIlroy's 3-iron club from a lake at Doral, presenting it to McIlroy before his final round. McIlroy used the club, but hit it into the water again, finishing tied for ninth. Trump plans to auction or display the club for charity.
references:
Zully Broussard decided to give a kidney to a stranger .
A new computer program helped her donation spur transplants for six kidney patients .

The 20th MLS season begins this weekend .
League has changed dramatically since its inception in 1996 .
Some question whether rules regarding salary caps and transfers need to change .

Bafetimbi Gomis collapses within 10 minutes of kickoff at Tottenham .
But he reportedly left the pitch conscious and wearing an oxygen mask .
Gomis later said that he was "feeling well"
The incident came three years after Fabrice Muamba collapsed at White Hart Lane .

Rory McIlroy throws club into water at WGC Cadillac Championship .
Northern Irishman frustrated after pulling shot into water hazard .

Cayman Naib, 13, hasn't been heard from since Wednesday .
Police, family, volunteers search for eighth-grader .

Ruben Navarrette: Schilling deserves praise for taking on online haters for offensive comments about his daughter .
Navarrette: In protecting his child, Schilling set a model for parenting and taught us a lesson about social media .

Two American women arrested for carving initials into a Colosseum wall .
Meanwhile, Egypt investigating Russian pornography film reportedly shot at Great Pyramids .
Cambodia's Angkor Archeological Park experienced a string of nudity-related incidents this year .

It will be a first time for the tour stateside .
